If education is to develop skills, knowledge, and attitudes which will per¬
petuate our form of society and strengthen the ideological and moral fiber of
the nation, we must pursue excellence with these goals in mind.
In the face of such compelling needs, where are we to find the means of
extending the scope and effectiveness of our educational resource?
The most feasible answer lies in the immediate and massive application
of technology, particularly in communications.
The Role of the New £1astanfeLMg^
When communications technology is skillfully used in the educational
process, it makes possible the extension of more learning to more people in
less time at less cost. This is especially true of television.
Research and experimentation have proved conclusively that television
can teach. Moreover it can extend the talents of gifted teachersasridely to
many people simultaneously. More importantly, television through its abUity
to provide close-up and magnified views, and incorporate other visual devices, and
introducing learning experiences not possible or normally available in the class¬
room , can improve the quality of the learning process.
Some of the educational uses of radio and television are:
to elementary and secondary schools—small organized instructional pro-
grams, particularly in subject areas when there is a shortage of competent
teachers.
In colleges and universities—distribution of lecture or laboratory demonstrations
to a large number of students on campus or at extension centers.
For Improvement of teaching—the impact upon teaching methodology caused
by imposing sharper discipline. In increasing the variety of teaching aids;
introducting innovations in the classroom; teacher-training through opportunities
for observation of classroom practices and teaching methods.
In pre-school instruction —programs to help prepare children for their first
formal school experiences by offering valid pre-school education aimed at
building attitudes and early skills.
In adult education—Informal education aimed at providing a rich cultural
fare through programs in the arts; a continuing learning resource via college
level credit and non-credit courses and vocational and professional training;
programs for functional illiterates, accurate information and informed opinion
about public issues as a basis for making informed judgments; and in¬
